description: This series is focused on CompTIA’s Security+ certifications. Security+ is a vendor-neutral certification that is recognized worldwide as a benchmark for information system security best practices. The series is intended for aspiring IT security professionals entering into security. The series follows the CompTIA specified objectives for the SY0-501 exam.
descriptionMD: This series is focused on CompTIA’s Security+ certifications. Security+ is a vendor-neutral certification that is recognized worldwide as a benchmark for information system security best practices. The series is intended for aspiring IT security professionals entering into security. The series follows the CompTIA specified objectives for the SY0-501 exam.
name: CompTIA Security+ 2017
subtitle: Vendor-neutral IT Security

episodes.description: This series is focused on CompTIA’s Security+ certifications. Security+ is a vendor-neutral certification that is recognized worldwide as a benchmark for information system security best practices. The series is intended for aspiring IT security professionals entering into security. The series follows the CompTIA specified objectives for the SY0-501 exam.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.780
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.780 --> 00:00:09.594
In this series, we're gonna be
looking at CompTIA's, vendor neutral,

3
00:00:09.594 --> 00:00:11.930
certification exam, known as Security+.

4
00:00:11.930 --> 00:00:15.860
We will, in the overview,
dive into, well what is Security+?

5
00:00:15.860 --> 00:00:18.715
As well as, who is this course for?

6
00:00:18.715 --> 00:00:21.510
We'll also be looking at some of the
topics that you can expect to be covered

7
00:00:21.510 --> 00:00:23.720
inside of the Security+ series.

8
00:00:23.720 --> 00:00:26.530
And, finally, we'll be looking
at some of the exam details so

9
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:28.940
when you decide to take
that certification exam and

10
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:32.620
sit the hot seat there,
you'll be a little bit better prepared.

11
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:37.350
So, let's go ahead, and let's talk about,
well, what is Security+ to begin with?

12
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:40.400
Well, Security+,
I said is a worldwide accreditation.

13
00:00:40.400 --> 00:00:45.300
It's recognized, just by about
126 different countries, or more,

14
00:00:45.300 --> 00:00:47.520
across the entire globe.

15
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:52.393
It is the benchmark for the best
practices that we see in IT security.

16
00:00:52.393 --> 00:00:56.898
It's also recognized by
international standards bodies, so

17
00:00:56.898 --> 00:01:01.404
the International Organization
of Standardization has an ISO

18
00:01:01.404 --> 00:01:04.133
accreditation known as 17024.

19
00:01:04.133 --> 00:01:09.120
It's also FISMA compliant too, the Federal
Information Security Management Act.

20
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:11.495
It's also recognized by the US Military,
as well.

21
00:01:11.495 --> 00:01:16.524
So keep in mind, if this is something
that you want to be involved in,

22
00:01:16.524 --> 00:01:22.100
these are some of the things that you
can expect to see inside of Security+.

23
00:01:22.100 --> 00:01:25.770
All right, so who is Security+ for?

24
00:01:25.770 --> 00:01:28.930
Well, anybody who is
an aspiring IT professional.

25
00:01:28.930 --> 00:01:32.930
If you are looking to learn how
to secure information systems,

26
00:01:32.930 --> 00:01:34.820
then Security+ is for you.

27
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:39.430
If you're seeking certification, well,
then this is the right series for you.

28
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:42.990
It could be that maybe you're just
seeking current security techniques and

29
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:43.940
technologies.

30
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:51.760
And if that's the case, then the Security+
SY0501 exam is going to be where it's at.

31
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:56.137
Next, what are we going to
cover inside of this exam.

32
00:01:56.137 --> 00:01:58.984
Well I kind of mentioned, briefly there,

33
00:01:58.984 --> 00:02:02.790
the exam code these are the new
objectives as of October.

34
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:09.470
This is the objectives for exam SY0501.

35
00:02:09.470 --> 00:02:13.150
We're gonna be looking at things like
the fundamental IT security concepts.

36
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:17.580
We'll also be taking a look at some of
the principle risk management concepts.

37
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:21.300
Things like the host based and
network based security techniques.

38
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:25.600
As well as things like your introductory
compliance and operational concepts.

39
00:02:25.600 --> 00:02:28.930
We'll also be looking at different
things like threats and vulnerabilities.

40
00:02:28.930 --> 00:02:32.220
We'll be looking at, not only threats and
vulnerabilities, but also attacks.

41
00:02:32.220 --> 00:02:34.290
We'll look at some of the technologies and

42
00:02:34.290 --> 00:02:39.540
tools you can expect to see if you're
making your way into an IT security field.

43
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:41.930
We'll also be looking at
things like architecture and

44
00:02:41.930 --> 00:02:46.020
design, very important in
today's information systems.

45
00:02:46.020 --> 00:02:48.840
We'll be looking at identity and
access management,

46
00:02:48.840 --> 00:02:53.020
a very important concept today when we
talk about enterprise based networks.

47
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:55.890
As well as the basics
of risk management and

48
00:02:55.890 --> 00:03:01.640
then finally we'll be talking about
cryptology and public key infrastructure.

49
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:05.530
Now, if you are getting into the exam,

50
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:07.760
there's some things you
might need to know about it.

51
00:03:07.760 --> 00:03:10.420
One of the things that we
want to look at is that

52
00:03:10.420 --> 00:03:14.010
the exam format is 90
questions in 90 minutes.

53
00:03:14.010 --> 00:03:17.060
It's multiple choice or
performance-based questions.

54
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:20.920
When we look at performance-based
questions, understand that that does imply

55
00:03:20.920 --> 00:03:23.770
that there could be simulations,
so be prepared for that.

56
00:03:23.770 --> 00:03:27.493
Now the passing score for
your Security+ exam is gonna be 750 and

57
00:03:27.493 --> 00:03:30.835
that's a passing score out
of a range from 100 to 900.

58
00:03:30.835 --> 00:03:35.678
As far as we know right now,
the Security+ exam

59
00:03:35.678 --> 00:03:40.620
is going to cost you $320 U.S. dollars.

60
00:03:40.620 --> 00:03:44.560
It is recommended that you
have CompTIA's Net+ and

61
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:47.370
two year's IT administration experience.

62
00:03:47.370 --> 00:03:50.400
However, keep in mind that
that is recommend but

63
00:03:50.400 --> 00:03:52.610
it is not a necessity before hand.

64
00:03:52.610 --> 00:03:56.710
It's not a pre-requisite to you taking the
actual exam, it's just a recommendation.

65
00:03:56.710 --> 00:03:58.720
So, if these are some of the concepts and

66
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:03.884
these are some of the goals that you
have to become IT security certified and

67
00:04:03.884 --> 00:04:07.580
prove the knowledge that
you have competency and

68
00:04:07.580 --> 00:04:10.810
security techniques in how to
secure information systems,

69
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:15.372
then the CompTIA Security+ SY0501
series is for you.

70
00:04:15.372 --> 00:04:18.652
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this show, Wes and Cherokee discuss several different types of malware. First, they explore virus variations such as boot sector, polymorphic, macro, stealth viruses and more! You will also hear them explain other associated attacks such as logic bombs and  ransomware. Tune in to learn what defines these types of attacks.
episodes.title: Determining Types of Malware

episodes.description: This is a continuation of a previous show discussion where Cherokee and Wes discuss several types of malware. They pick up explaining how a worm is different from a virus. Next, they cover trojans, rootkits, keyloggers and adware.
episodes.title: Determining Types of Malware Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Wes explain numerous types of attacks one should be aware of. Specifically, they begin looking at social engineering. Tune in to learn how phishing, spear phishing, whaling, vishing, tailgating, impersonation, dumpster diving, shoulder surfing, hoaxes, and watering hole attacks are all related.
episodes.title: Types of Attacks

episodes.description: This a continuation of a previous conversation where Cherokee and Wes discuss several types of attacks. They talk about different types of Denial of Service (DoS) and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS), Man-in-the-Middle (MitM), Buffer overflow, injection, Cross-site Scripting (XSS) and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF or XSRF), Privilege Escalation and more! Tune in to get all of the details.
episodes.title: Types of Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: Wes and Cherokee continue to cover many different types of attack methods. They pick up from a Previous DNS poisoning conversation and segue into the topics of hijacking and associated techniques an attacker may use. Wes explains shimming, ,spoofing, and various 802.11 type attacks.
episodes.title: Types of Attacks Part 3

episodes.description: Cherokee and Wes continue speaking about wireless attack methods,  they specifically focus on wireless transmission attacks that may be associated with Bluetooth, RFID and NFC. Tune in to watch them round out this multi-part topic.
episodes.title: Types of Attacks Part 4

episodes.description: In this show, Wes and Cherokee explain the different types of threat actors and vectord used to execute an attack. Attacks are not always a one size fits all, sometimes they may incorporate many techniques. Tune in to learn more.
episodes.title: Threat Vector Types and Attributes

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes discuss concepts associates with penetration testing. They explain different levels of tests such as black, grey and white box testing. Tune in to learn additional methods used to test an organizations security.
episodes.title: Penetration Testing Concepts

episodes.description: This episode focuses on what the possible repercussions of one may encounter if a vulnerability is exercised. Watch Wes and Cherokee explain situations to be aware of such as Race conditions, End-of-life systems, Embedded systems, and improper input/error handling,
episodes.title: Impact of Various Vulnerabilities

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes continue their previous discussion by explaining how improperly configured accounts can impact an organizations security. They also talk about memory buffer vulnerabilities, architecture or design weaknesses, zero day attacks, and improper certificate and key management.
episodes.title: Impact of Various Vulnerabilities Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes begin a discussion focused on understanding how both hardware and software impact an organizations security. They begin examining different firewalls and the importance of their configurations. They continue to cover many topics such as VPN Concentrators, Network Intrusion/Prevention Systems, and routers.
episodes.title: Hardware Software Organizational Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Cherokee take a look at IPSec and how it can be used for transmitting information. They also discuss what a proxy is and how it may offer different functionalities based upon how it is implemented.
episodes.title: Hardware Software Organizational Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes begin discussing why one may want to use load balancing and the many ways it can be implemented. They also cover topics such as access points, Security Information and Event Management systems (SIEM), and Data Loss/Leakage Prevention (DLP) techniques.
episodes.title: Hardware Software Organizational Security Part 3

episodes.description: Cherokee and Wes continue to examine how both hardware and software can impact security. In this episode they discuss several concepts such as Network Access Control (NAC), Mail Gateway, Bridges, SSL/TLS accelerators, SSL decryptors, Mail Gateways and Hardware Security Modules (HSM's).
episodes.title: Hardware Software Organizational Security Part 4

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes begin a discussion focused on software-based utilities that can assist in remaining compliant with an organizations security posture. Wes demonstrates several tools such as Wireshark, Nexpose and other wireless scanners.
episodes.title: Security Posture Assessment

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue a conversation about tools that can be used to assist posture assessment compliance. Wes shows chow to use and navigate through a vulnerability scanner.
episodes.title: Security Posture Assessment Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Wes and Cherokee continue to share tools to assist in assist posture assessment compliance. First,  they suggest how to sanitize drives by overwriting at a bit a bit level depending on different regulatory compliance. Next, they discuss steganography tools to be aware of. Lastly, they explain the benefits of setting up a honeypot or honeynet.
episodes.title: Security Posture Assessment Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes round off a discussion centered around software-based solutions that assist organization adhere to their security posture. Specifically, they begin looking at different backup options. With the advent of cloud-based solutions we see an expansion of redundancy options which Wes covers. Lastly, they look at command line utilities to assist in both Windows and Nix-based systems.
episodes.title: Security Posture Assessment Part 4

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes begin to cover different issues one may have to troubleshoot. They begin explaining protocols that send information in clear or plain text such as FTP, Telnet, PAP and HTTP. Nest they discuss the importance of logs, permissions, access violations and certificate issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Common Security Issues

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue to examine common issues that one may encounter.  They point out insecure protocols, missing log information, permission issues, access violations and more. Tune in now to learn techniques and tips that may help mitigate problems one might face.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Common Security Issues Part 2

episodes.description: With the vast selection of tools available it may not be difficult to find one to suite your needs, however learning all of those tools may not always come without some practice. Tune in to watch Cherokee and Wes demonstrate how to interpret the output of some commonly used tools.
episodes.title: Analyze and Interpret Outputs

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes continue to analyze and interpret the output of various tools. They begin with firewalls and continue to examine additional tools such as Microsoft's AppLocker followed with assorted malware utilities.
episodes.title: Analyze and Interpret Outputs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes discuss the importance of mobile security. Because mobile devices have become such an integral part of our lives it is imperative to address the potential vulnerabilities and weaknesses. Tune in now to learn how to increase security while using these devices.
episodes.title: Deploy Mobile Security

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes stess the importance of not only knowing what secure protocols are but rather one should also understand why they should not use the insecure counterpart. They also mention that in addition to understanding these protocols it is very important to be able to recognize the port numbers associated with these protocols for proper configuration and network analysis.
episodes.title: Implement Secure Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore common best practices and security configuration guides covered in the Security+ exam. Here they look into industry standard frameworks to secure specialized environments, defense-in-depth guides, and user training. All these are used to make the securing of a networked system easier and consistent.
episodes.title: Best Practices and Secure Config Guides

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes explain how the successful network designs can improve the overall network security. Tune in to learn what they recommend.
episodes.title: Secure Network Architecture Concepts

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes explain how the design of individual devices may add  an additional layer of security. Tune in to learn several suggestions for consideration when choosing what type of devices to use within your environment.
episodes.title: Secure System Design

episodes.description: Wes and Zach breakdown secure staging deployment concepts, what is sandboxing and why its important, environment types including Development-Test-Staging-Production, Secure Baseline, then concluding with what is Integrity Measurement.
episodes.title: Secure Staging Deployment Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes discuss the security implications of embedded systems. They explain how SCADA systems can be used to perform pretty serious attacks. They also point out additional elements to consider such as IoT devices, HVAC systems, systems on a chip (SoC) and real-time operating system (RTOS) to name a few.
episodes.title: Security Implications of Embedded Systems

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the development and deployment of secure applications. Here they explore development life-cycle models like Waterfall and Agile. They also discuss secure DevOps, version control and change management, secure coding techniques, code quality and testing, and compiled vs. runtime code.
episodes.title: Secure App Development and Deployment

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes introduce you to different cloud and virtualization concepts. Here you will learn about Hypervisors, Cloud Storage, and Cloud deployment models like IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS. They also discuss the difference between On-premise vs. hosted vs. cloud and start their look into VDI/VDE.
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtualization Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue their look into Cloud and Virtualization concepts. Here they pick back up with their discussion on Virtual Desktop Infrastructure(VDI/VDE). They also cover cloud access security brokers, VM Sprawl avoidance, and VM escape protections.
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtalization Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain how to use automation and resiliency to reduce risk. Here they show you how through the use of standard procedures and automated task you can reduce the amount of common error through human fallibility. Other topics include Elasticity, Scalability, Redundancy, Fault Tolerance, and High Availability.
episodes.title: Resiliency and Automation to Reduce Risk

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes stress the importance  of physical security controls. They explain how each layer of security adds complexity. They offer several suggestions that can be implemented to improve an organizations security. Tune in to learn how airgaps, mantraps, lighting and more can help your network!
episodes.title: Importance of Physical Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes continue to explain how physical security is an integral part of an organizations security posture. They begin by discussing Faraday cages, lock types, biometrics and so much more. Tune in to see what else they recommend for network security.
episodes.title: Importance of Physical Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look into identity and access management concepts. Here they discuss Identification, Authentication/Authorization/Accounting (AAA), and Multi-factor Authentication practices.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through a litany of Identity and Access services. Here they discuss services like LDAP, Kerberos, PAP/CHAP/MSCHAP, RADIUS/TACACS+, SAML, OpenID Connect, OATH, Shibboleth, and NTLM.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into common Identity and Access Management Controls covered in the Security+ exam. Here you'll learn about access control models like MAC, DAC, RBAC, and ABAC. They also cover physical access, certificate-based controls, and biometric factors.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Controls

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at common Identity and Access Management controls. Here they cover the use of Token based systems, (both hardware and software), file system security, and database security.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Controls Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore common account management practices. Here they will review the different account types like user accounts, service accounts, and privileged accounts.
episodes.title: Account Management Practices

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue discussing common account management practices. They pick back up looking at general security practices like recertification, time restrictions, and group-based access control. They also go over account policy enforcement techniques.
episodes.title: Account Management Practices Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into Policies, Plans, and Procedures. Here they cover different agreement types like BPA, SLA, ISA, and MOU/MOA. Then they go over proper personnel management for risk reduction. Other topics covered includes NDAs, Onboarding, and Acceptable Use Policies.
episodes.title: Policies, Plans and Procedures

episodes.description: Wes and Zach cover identifying critical systems, privacy threshold assessments, privacy impact assessments, and mission essential functions.
episodes.title: Impact Business Analysis

episodes.description: Wes and Zach explain risk management processes and concepts, what are the components of threat assessments, the differences between internal and external assessments, risk assessment, ALE=SLE *ARO - quantitative assessment, plus risk response techniques (or strategies).
episodes.title: Risk Management Processes and Concepts

episodes.description: Wes and Zach identify incident types with appropriate response process & measures. Documentation at all levels is emphasized.
episodes.title: Incident Response Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin their discussion of the basics of computer forensics. Topics covered include Order of Volatility, Chain of Custody, Data Acquisition, and Strategic Intelligence Gathering.
episodes.title: Basic Concepts of Forensics

episodes.description: Wes and Zach go over options in recovery sites, protocol or order for restoration, plus backup concepts.
episodes.title: Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity

episodes.description: Wes and Zach recap considerations about backup, geographic considerations, legal implications including data sovereignty, and operation planning.
episodes.title: Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes explain how to handle data past its useful life and and what one should consider whilst retaining data. They cover digital methods to dispose of data such as formatting and wiping as well as physical destruction methods. Tune in hear them cover other aspects of privacy as well.
episodes.title: Data Security and Privacy

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes go over the basic concepts of Cryptography. Here they look at topics like symmetric/asymmetric algorithms, modes of operation, hashing and salting, which is a method used to increase the defense of hashing.
episodes.title: Basic Concepts of Cryptography

episodes.description: Wes and Zach discuss the science of hiding data, and working with principles of encryption. Sub-topics include Elliptic Curve, Digital Signatures, the difference between Diffusion and Confusion, Ephemeral Key, Data States, and more.
episodes.title: Basic Concepts of Cryptography Part 2

episodes.description: Wes and Zach cover what are cryptography algorithms, basic characteristics, different types of cyphertext, encryption keys, difference between block & stream cyphers, symmetric & asymmetric algorithms, and more.
episodes.title: Cryptography Algorithms Basics

episodes.description: Wes and Zach go over cypher modes & what they are, hashing algorithms, key stretching algorithms, what a Hashing Collision is, obfuscation, substitution cyphers, and deciding what are the best applications for your systems.
episodes.title: Cryptography Algorithms Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes take a look at concepts such as hash algorithms including MD5, SHA, HMAC, and RIPEMD. They also look additional obfuscation methods such as key stretching algorithms, XORing, using ROT ciphers and substitution ciphers.
episodes.title: Cryptography Algorithms Basics Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore wireless security for the Security+ exam. Here they cover cryptographic protocols like WEP, WPA/WPA2, and TKIP. They also look at authentication protocols like EAP, PEAP, IEEE 802.1x, and RADIUS.
episodes.title: Wireless Security

episodes.description: In this show Wes and Cherokee begin discussing public key infrastructure. Learn the basic design of a Certificate Authority hierarchy and learn terms such as CRL, OCSP and more!
episodes.title: Public Key Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes continue discussing Public Key Infrastructure. First, they examine components for validation followed by additional concepts such as certificate pinning, key escrow and wildcards. Next, they look at different levels of validation and certificate formats.
episodes.title: Public Key Infrastructure Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue to examine the different ways certificates can be used.  Wes explains how to structure a Certificate Authority depending on your organizations need.
episodes.title: Public Key Infrastructure Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue to explain PKI. Wes also demonstrates how create and configure a Root CA. He also sets up a subordinate s CA in Windows Server 2012.
episodes.title: Public Key Infrastructure Part 4
